Award.AwardTitle: Geochemical constraints on the source, flux, migration, and seismic signature of volcanic fluids, Katmai Volcanic Cluster, Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fluid movement in the subsurface of active volcanoes is frequently thought to produce abundant seismicity (i.e. earthquakes); however the actual type of fluid, including magma, volcanic gases, or hydrothermal waters, and the implications of the fluid movement cannot currently be constrained from seismic data. Knowledge of the type of fluid/s in the subsurface is critical for both forecasting volcanic eruption and estimating the explosivity of the impending eruption. Through comparison of high temporal resolution measurements of volcanic gas composition and seismicity, it may be possible to identify the type of fluid associated with unique seismic signatures. The ability to identify magma movement from seismic data will enable scientists to better determine the likelihood and/or timing of impending eruptions.

In this project, geochemical measurements of volcanic fluids and complementary seismic data from three historically-active Alaskan volcanoes will be used to: (1) determine the source (i.e. subducted slab, mantle, crust) and flux of volcanic gases, (2) determine proportions of magmatic and hydrothermal fluids within the subsurface, and (3) distinguish trends in gas composition and/or flux that correlate with seismic signatures of fluid movement. Gas composition will be combined with total gas flux to help elucidate subduction and magma generation processes. Daily measurements of gas composition and flux will be compared with seismic data collected over a two-month period to help determine the type of fluid movement associated with certain seismic signals. This project will answer fundamental science questions applicable to GeoPRISMS objectives, specifically regarding the storage, transfer, and release of volcanic fluids, and the relationship between subduction and surface processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluid movement in the subsurface of active volcanoes is frequently thought to produce abundant seismicity (i.e. earthquakes); however the actual type of fluid, including magma, volcanic gases, or hydrothermal waters, and the implications of the fluid movement cannot currently be constrained from seismic data. Knowledge of the type of fluid/s in the subsurface is critical for both forecasting volcanic eruption and estimating the explosivity of the impending eruption.

In this project, we collected geochemical measurements of volcanic fluids and complementary seismic data from three persistently degassing and seismically active Alaskan volcanoes: Mount Martin, Mount Mageik and Trident. We used the chemical and isotopic composition of the measured volcanic fluids to identify sediment, most likely from the crust, and the mantle, as the primary sources of deep fluids at these volcanoes. This suggests that the subducted slab entering the Aleutian trench may be depleted in certain fluids typically associated with subduction and resulting arc volcanism such as carbon and nitrogen. The composition of volcanic fluids from all three volcanoes indicates the presence of both magma and hydrothermal waters in the subsurface, with Mount Martin’s fluids having a greater magmatic component relative to Mount Mageik and Trident, whose fluids are largely hydrothermal in composition. The presence of both shallow magma and hydrothermal waters make these volcanoes susceptible to highly-explosive phreatic eruptions where hot magma interacts with liquid water and quickly converts it to steam. Therefore distinguishing seismicity caused by migration of hydrothermal fluids, magmatic gases and magma is important for forecasting eruptions and mitigating the associated hazards. Using continuous measurements of plume composition and seismicity at Mount Martin, we identify a temporal correlation between a more magmatic plume composition and the occurrence of a specific repeating earthquake. This observation suggests that this earthquake ‘family’ is caused by the migration and outgassing of volcanic gases at the volcano’s surface. This important finding indicates that volcanic fluid geochemistry can be used with seismic data to identify the type of fluid movement associated with certain seismic signatures, which will help scientists better interpret seismic data and better forecast volcanic eruptions.

In addition to the scientific findings, this project also provided an exceptional learning opportunity for a young-scientist of under-represented demographics to organize and execute a scientifically relevant research project, develop strong interdisciplinary collaborations with national and international partners, and identify a new research tool to help improve eruption forecasting capabilities and mitigate volcanic hazards.
